Expectation1: Teaching children moral values and discipline
Situation1: The child is caught stealing snacks at a store, and the step-parent needs to handle the situation
Expectation2: Meet sales targets set by management
Situation2: On the final day of the quarter, the team must hit the cumulative target to avoid penalties and secure bonuses.
Story: I was standing in the fluorescent-lit aisle of the grocery store, my phone buzzing insistently in my pocket. My stepson, Jamie, stood beside me, his face pale and eyes wide as the store manager explained how he’d been caught slipping a candy bar into his jacket. My mind raced—this was the moment I was supposed to teach him right from wrong, to show him that actions have consequences, to be the responsible adult he needed. But my phone kept vibrating, each buzz a reminder that it was the last day of the quarter, and my sales manager had made it clear: if I didn’t close at least three more deals today, the whole team would miss our target. The pressure was suffocating. I could almost hear my manager’s voice in my head, urging me to get back on the phone, to not let everyone down. But Jamie needed me, right now, to be present, to guide him through this mistake. My heart pounded as I looked from Jamie’s trembling hands to the phone in my pocket, torn between the demands of my job and the responsibility I felt as his step-parent.
